title: mum told lesions forehead were
story: NewsMum told lesions on her forehead were psoriasis but doctors later revealed devastating cancer diagnosisSelf-confessed sun worshipper Margaret 'Mags' Murphy, 47, has opened up about her battle with skin cancer&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmma Costello03:19, 7 JUL 2018Updated09:40, 7 JUL 2018NewsDoctors intitially told Mags Murphy she was suffering from psoriasis&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA self-confessed sun worshipper was told she had skin cancer seven years after being misdiagnosed by doctors. Margaret 'Mags' Murphy from Dublin, Ireland had grown concerned about lesions on her forehead - which doctors initially claimed was psoriasis. But further inspection showed that this was skin cancer, and that she would need treatment. The mum explained that she had lesions on her forehead that had been there for years but wouldn't go away. She told Dublin Live : Seven years before I was diagnosed, one dermatologist told me it was psoriasis. But then the lesions started to blister, I could feel them tingle all the time. Mags then went to her doctor in Dublin, who referred her to St James' Hospital but was told she wouldn't hear back from them for 18 months to two years.  The Dubliner wasn't in a rush about getting her lesions checked because they were hidden by her hair, so she waited the two years before going back to her doctor in 2016. Mags continued: She sent in an urgent referral and I heard back in a couple of weeks. After she finally got an appointment made with the hospital, Mags was diagnosed with pre-cancerous cells. The 47-year-old was then given a treatment called efudex, which is a type of chemotherapy you can do from home. She wasn't scared by what happened after living 13 years in Greece, adding that she wasn't surprised. Mags said: I liked the sun and my mother had been through the same treatment.  I knew it could be treated. I was able to have the cancerous cells frozen off but because of my history, they said there could be more that haven't shown up yet so they treated my whole face. Mags explained that even though the lesions on her face looked the worst, it was actually her chin that was worst affected despite having no visible signs.  Her whole body was given the treatment and she shared her journey on her blogs, Mags Murphy's Journey. She set up the blog so she could help others understand what the process was. She said: A lot of doctors can't really advice you because they haven't done the treatment I went through, so people have come to me and said the blog has helped them know that they're going through the same steps. Speaking about the appearance of her cancer, she said that they weren't moles but dry patches. Related video - A doctor posted this video on Facebook to find woman with a cancerous lump

title: new aptamil baby milk formula
story: NewsNew Aptamil baby milk formula is making babies sick claim parentsDanone insists its product has been tested and is safe to consume&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmma Gill10:28, 7 JUL 2018NewsSarah Foster with baby Tobi, who had a bad reaction to the new formula milk (Image: MEN Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Furious parents have hit out at a the makers of a popular formula milk, claiming its new recipe is making their babies sick.   Aptamil has changed its First Infant milk powder in recent weeks, but parents have flooded the product's Facebook page with complaints.   They say youngsters are being sick and suffering from diarrhoea after drinking the new milk, the Manchester Evening News reported.  Some mums have shared photos of the feeds, saying the milk is curdling and the powder doesn't dissolve.  And they say Danone, which makes Aptamil and insists the new recipe is safe to drink, has given different explanations to concerned families. Sarah Foster said her eight-week-old son Tobi had been fine on the old milk since birth, but became ill after trying the new tub. She told the paper: He was sick straight away when feeding him the first feed of it. As soon as it hit his tummy it was back up. It was then I noticed it didn’t mix the same. I’ve since stockpiled the old formula but it will only last a week or two. We have no choice but to use the new one as everywhere has sold out or no longer stocks the old one.  Sarah, 35, also mum to seven-year-old Joshua, says the company is giving various responses to customers who have complained. She added: I’m so annoyed and upset about this as Aptamil are giving different answers to different people, from blaming how mums are making up the formula and then backtracking. I’ve got my replies from them through Facebook messenger and you can tell they're generic responses despite coming from a person. Parents have also complained the company has reduced the size of its packs from 900g to 800g while keeping the tubs at the same price.  Bel Garner shared a Facebook post about the new formula earlier this week and has since received more than 200 messages from people having similar issues. The experienced mum-of-three, said she was offended by the suggestion mums could be making the feeds up wrong and has criticised the new guidance to make the milk using water that's cooled for half an hour. She said: Aptamil please tell me what magical skill I have to tell my 4 1/2 old month baby that she has to wait 30 minutes for her bottle (more so if you have a baby that’s not in a routine or feeds on demand) as we are advised as parents NOT to pre-make bottles and to make each feed up as we need it and to cool down with cold water for immediate use.  Mum Susan Johnston, whose daughter was being very sick, refusing feeds and suffering with diarrhoea, posted a photo of one bottle made up with the old formula and one with the new to show the company the difference between the two. She said: The pictures I took were of Aptamil old and new formula. Why is there such a difference between the two when they were both made at same time in the same way? And another mum Amanda Higson, urged the company to take action over the number of complaints. She said: I don’t think it’s a coincidence a lot of babies are getting poorly on the new First Infant milk. Why change the formula when it was fine? I think this should be looked into as a priority, either bring the old milk back or look into why babies are reacting so badly to the new one. In the heat/weather at the moment it’s even more of a priority when babies are either not taking to the milk or being sick/upset tummy and losing fluids. Sort it Aptamil, very disappointing.

title: pippa middleton reveals one thing
story: NewsPippa Middleton reveals the one thing she's refusing to give up during her pregnancyPippa Middleton is expecting her first child with husband James Matthews&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer17:36, 6 JUL 2018NewsPippa is pregnant with her first child (Image: Rex)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen women find out they're pregnant, their lives change forever. Even though they're still months away from meeting their baby, the changes to their day-to-day life start immediately. There's a whole host of foods they can no longer eat, they can't drink and they will sometimes have to give up the hobbies they love. But there's one thing Pippa Middleton, who is expecting her first child with husband James Matthews, is refusing to give up despite that growing baby bump.   Writing in her column for Waitrose Weekend , the Duchess of Cambridge's little sister, 34, explains why she is still playing tennis.  She said: I've been a tennis fan since childhood, as player and spectator, and have been keen to continue playing safely throughout pregnancy. Take Serena Williams – she famously proved that women can play a high level of tennis from two months (when she won the 2017 Australian Open) up to eight months. Few of us can relate to this elite excellence, but if you're a healthy, well-trained player with an uncomplicated pregnancy there's no reason why you can't continue a good level of tennis.  It is believed Pippa is due in October. And it's not just playing which Pippa enjoys, and she's a regular at Wimbledon. She was in the crowds for day four of this year's competition with her brother James.

title: town shuts shopping streets today
story: NewsTown shuts shopping streets today for "public safety" during England World Cup match fearing 'intimidating' celebrationsCouncillors in Ashby, Leicestershire, have denied being World Cup "killjoys"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlan Thompson09:46, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A town centre will close its shopping streets during the England World Cup match over fears wild fan celebrations will intimidate people.  England will take on Sweden at 3pm today in a crucial quarter-final clash, but shops and two streets in Ashby, Leicestershire, will be shut down for the duration.  The controversial move comes after police were called in when large numbers of chanting England supporters marched down a street on Tuesday night after Gareth Southgate's side beat Colombia on penalties.    Video showed some people clambering on top of a lorry amid rowdy scenes in the town, LeicestershireLive reported.  And Leicestershire County Council says Market Street and Brook Street in the town centre will now be closed between 2pm and 6.30pm today for public safety. It is not thought that any damage was caused during Tuesday's high-spirited celebrations, but businesses are not taking any chances. Ashby town councillor and business owner John Coxon said that celebrations around the games could sometimes be intimidating. He said: I think some of the business owners are fearful of what might happen. Our neighbours have said they’re going to close early rather than risk any aggravation. People like to celebrate and it’s understandable, but for some it can be a bit intimidating. Like most market towns, businesses in Ashby can’t afford to lose 25 per cent of their trade on a Saturday.

title: uk weather england world cup
story: NewsUK weather: England World Cup fans to bask in 33C heat on 'hottest day of the year'Saturday afternoon is set to be a scorcher as about 30 million people watch England's quarter final on TV&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChris kitching08:26, 7 JUL 2018Updated10:21, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA heatwave is doing its part for the millions of England fans set to watch the Three Lions' World Cup showdown with Sweden. But will England give them something to celebrate in the glorious sunshine and 33C heat? Saturday afternoon is set to be a scorcher as a record 30 million people watch the quarter final clash on TV. Temperatures could be the hottest of the year so far as football fans battle the heat as well as their nerves - but there is a risk of isolated showers in some places.  Porthmadog in Wales is the current record holder, reaching 33C exactly on June 28, but this weekend the thermometer could edge just above it. But the sweltering conditions pose a health risk, especially to vulnerable Brits including the elderly. The Met Office and Public Health England this week upgraded their heatwave alert to amber - the second highest level, below red - for western regions of England.  A yellow alert is in place for eastern regions. The alerts mean people should take precautions to avoid being struck down by heat-related illnesses. Football fans will be lighting up their barbecues, stocking their fridges with beer and gathering in huge numbers to watch the World Cup action from the Cosmos Arena in Samara, Russia.    Here at home, fans are expected to sink around 38 million pints, with supermarkets braced for a beer and food frenzy. Big screens have been set up for supporters in many cities, and street parties are planned all over England. Met Office spokeswoman Nicola Maxey said temperatures in London and south east are likely to reach 31C and 32C, with isolated weather stations potentially reaching 33C on Saturday and possibly Sunday.  We could well see the hottest day of the year so far this weekend. It's only got to go to 33.1C (91.6F) and you're there, she said. The football starts at 3pm, and temperatures are set to reach their highest in the afternoon. Everywhere across the south will enjoy temperatures in the high 20s and even low 30s, but almost the entire country will be feeling the heat. It's not just in the south east, but the peak is likely to be the south east over the weekend, Ms Maxey said.  She also warned of isolated showers in London on Saturday, potentially in the afternoon. I don't suppose anybody minds. They're all going to be inside watching the football, she joked. While the hot weather is ideal for a big celebration, the continuing heatwave is causing problems for water companies, which are urging customers to curb their use to prevent potential hosepipe bans. United Utilities - which serves the North West - said it urgently needed help and support to stop a ban from coming into force, while a hosepipe ban is into its second week in Northern Ireland. The amber and yellow heatwave alerts will remain in place to the middle of next week when temperatures take a slight dip.  The elderly, young children and those with heart and lung conditions are at greater risk. Public Health England said it has seen an increase in cases of sunburn, sunstroke, heatstroke and insect bites during the two-week heatwave. It has offered the following advice to beat the heat:  Stay out of the sun. Keep your home as cool as possible - shading windows and shutting them during the day may help. Open them when it is cooler at night. Keep drinking fluids, especially water. Carry water with you when you travel. Check on family, friends or neighbours who might be at special risk - for example, an older person living on their own.  Children and pets should not be left alone in cars. Amber, or level three, is the second highest level on the heatwave scale. It is issued when the thresholds have been exceeded. A red alert, or level four, is issued when a prolonged hot spell becomes severe. At that level, illness and death may occur among the fit and healthy, and not just in high-risk groups, the Met Office said.

title: uk weather scorching britain hot
story: NewsUK weather: Britain boils during 33C heatwave as sweltering commuters strip-off on hottest day, roads melt and Wimbledon fans sizzleTemperatures remain above average for the 12th day in the row as the country is in the midst of its longest heatwave since 1976 - and it's set to get hotter tomorrow&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline ReporterRachel Bishop17:41, 6 JUL 2018Updated23:14, 6 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCommuters were left sweltering in packed-out trains and tubes and roads have started metling as the sweltering 33C heatwave continues. Today is expected to top the previous hottest day record of 32C - and temperatures are going to stay high this weekend as England take on Sweden in the World Cup. Tourists and workers in London suffered through boiling conditions as they travelled home tonight as they faced temperatures of up to 35C on packed tube carriages. A signal failure at White City in west London brought chaos to the central line - with one station announcer saying he wasn't sure if the train would be waiting at the station for five minutes, five hours, or five years.  The central line consistently breaks records with temperatures peaking at 35.5C last summer - this exceeds the EU limit of 30C at which it is legal to transport cows, sheep and pigs. Trains from Paddington were also delayed due to an electricity failure and trains from Liverpool Street disrupted thanks to a points failure - causing thousands of people to wait in stations in the unberable hear. As the heatwave has raged on for nearly two weeks passengers travelling through Essex said people have fainted on trains as they travel home in 28C to 30C heat.  Some have hit out at rail firms by comparing the conditions on packed trains to a sauna with no air conditioning and barely any room to move. As the temperatures remain above average for the 12th day in the row Wimbledon fans were seen struggling as they watched on day five of the championships. Fans were seen fanning themselves and trying to cover their skin to avoid getting burnt as they tried to focus on the game. And this morning 'official pigeon scarer' Rufus the Hawk had to begin his daily shift at 5am on Centre Court to avoid the heat. Yesterday a West Berkshire Council bin lorry got stuck in Newbury yesterday after the road melted beneath it.  Thames Valley Police said the street had to be closed overnight to enable the damage to be assessed causing travel chaos through the town centre. Drivers have also been warned about driving in extreme temperatures over fears driving in the intense heat is almost like driving with a blood-alcohol reading. SEAT have published new information on driving in extreme temperatures, warning that people who make mistakes with their air conditioning during the intense heatwave risk lowering their driving ability.    A koi carp called 'Big White Fish' has even been rushed to hospital this week after getting burnt in the ongoing hot weather. Owner Pat Smythe, 70, from Burton-on-Trent noticed a big patch of red scales on his back and rushed him to the vet. Pet owners have been urged to take measures to stop their animals getting sunburn - with dogs , rabbits, cats, cows and even goldfish at risk - as the country is in the midst of its longest heatwave since 1976. Derby vet Paul Revell said: Believe it or not, fish can get sunburnt if they spend too long at the surface of a pond or lake.  There could be some relief from the heat for a brief period this weekend as some scattered showers will develop over Britain but most areas will remain dry and warm. An amber level heatwave alert has been issued for western parts of England with temperatures soaring over the next few days. London and the South East will bear the brunt of the sweltering conditions and high pressure will dominate the weather with prolonged periods of sunshine and more scorching air from the continent blocking any periods of cooler, unsettled Atlantic conditions. This has created an area of clear air above the UK, where cloud is suppressed and winds have been low to allow maximum heat to come through from the sun.  Hot conditions are expected to continue into next week. It may be sporadically cloudy and slightly fresher in the northwest at times with a little more rain or drizzle . However, for those wanting a respite from the heat, there is some hope on the horizon. More unsettled weather may start to develop later this month with occasional spells of more changeable conditions edging across the UK, particularly in the north and northwest.

title: voice mirror whole country knows
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: The whole country knows it's coming home timeRarely has an England team been so deserving of our support&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByVoice of the Mirror21:19, 6 JUL 2018NewsopinionTake your pick – or your Pickford, if you will – of any one of the squad (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe don’t need to tell you to set your watches, get the shopping done early, water the plants and finish the chores. The whole country knows what it will be doing at 3pm today – cheering England on. Rarely has an England team been so deserving of our support.  The tone has been set by the gaffer, Gareth Southgate, who has shown that nice guys can come first. Then there’s the heroics of Harry Kane, the bulldog spirit of Harry Maguire, and Marcus Rashford’s silky skills.  There’s the resilience of John Stones and the enthusiasm of Raheem Sterling. Take your pick – or your Pickford, if you will – of any one of the squad.

title: world cup england grinds halt
story: NewsEngland grinds to halt as record 30 MILLION to watch World Cup match with SwedenAround 38 million pints are expected to be sunk at home and in boozers as the temperature hits 33C&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJeremy ArmstrongRuki SayidConsumer EditorAndy Lines07:55, 7 JUL 2018Updated10:53, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe nation will today come to a standstill as England take on Sweden in the latest round of their quest for World Cup glory. With temperatures hitting up to 33C, millions of fans are expected to light up the barbecues and stock up fridges with cold beers. And they will be hoping Gareth Southgate’s boys also put on a sizzling display to beat the &shyScandinavians in our first World Cup quarter final for 12 years. A record 30 million viewers are expected to watch the clash on TV, along with 5,000 fans at the Cosmos Arena in red-hot Samara.  And the match has given retailers a &pound6.5billion boost as supporters buoyed by England’s fantastic run in the competition flock to buy replica kits, booze and food. That is better then last year’s Boxing Day sales record of &pound4.3billion. A study by Kellogg’s said over the course of the month-long World Cup families will splash out an average of &pound237 on the tournament.  The cereal firm said: “New research reveals UK families will spend around &pound6.5billion across Britain. As England goes from strength to strength in this year’s World Cup, families will splurge almost &pound2.5billion on footie merchandise.” Around 38 million pints are expected to be sunk at home and in boozers, with pub takings expecting to top Christmas Eve sales, hitting around &pound100million. And take-home drinks could bring in &pound22million, BBPA &shysupermarket and off-licence sales data indicated. &shyWetherspoon spokesman Eddie Gershon said: “Christmas Eve is a busy night but an England knockout game is a different dimension. We will be very busy.”    The British Beer and Pub Association added: “The 3pm kick-off helps pubs as it is early in the day and the good weather helps trade.” Asda said it is expecting to flog 8.5 million sausages over a 48-hour period as part of its Operation It’s Coming Home. It said: “Operation It’s Coming Home has been brewing for a while. We’re prepared, the England boys are prepared, &shyhopefully our customers are prepared… it’s coming home.” Tesco is expected to sell four million burgers, 3.5 million sausages, 50 million bottles of beer and a million bottles of wine.  Kantar Worldpanel strategic insight director Matt Botham said: “We’re looking at an extra four million trips to the shops on Friday and Saturday. Retailers need to make sure they’re prepared for the extra &shyfootfall on a stock and staffing level. “Long queues and empty shelves just before kick-off will not go down well with shoppers. “Alcohol will be the big winner. We’d expect sales to go up by a whopping 25% and over 30% of the extra shopping trips made would include alcohol in some format.”  Sainsbury’s, M&ampS and Iceland were also braced for a beer and food frenzy in the run up to the kick-off today. Morrison’s has slashed the price of Piper Heidsieck champagne from &pound30 to &pound19.66 in honour of our World Cup winning team. But stores in London’s Oxford Street are expecting a significant downturn in trade as the high streets empty ahead of kick-off. Apart from those supporters watching at home, millions more will pour into fan zones, pubs, bars and clubs to see the game.

title: world cup super fans rearrange
story: NewsWorld Cup super fans rearrange their own wedding so they can watch England matchThe football-mad couple are making sure they can watch the whole quarter final game against Sweden, even if it goes to penalties&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPeter CraigPippa Allen-Kinross10:03, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A couple who are set to get married today have rearranged the entire day to make sure they can watch England in the quarter finals of the World Cup .   As soon as Eric Dier scored the winning penalty for England in Tuesday night's cliffhanger with Columbia, football-mad groom Nick Hawley was on the phone to wedding planners to rearrange the time of his wedding .  The Cleethorpes couple's reception has even been pushed back until 5.30pm, just in case the match goes to penalties.  Bride Sue Potter said:  England had better bring the World Cup home after all the sacrifice I have made on my big day.   I knew as soon as they won that it was all going to get changed. Up until then it was all going swimmingly.  Sue, 43, who owns The Picnic Stop sandwich bar and cafe in Cleethorpes, told Grimsby Liv e Nick had persuaded the hotel to bring the ceremony forward to 2.30pm and asked the reception venue to postpone the speeches until 5.30pm.  The couple, who have been together for 18 years, are getting married in a small ceremony on Gretna Green, and will be joined by their daughters Ellie Stevenson, 24, and Libby Hawley, 13. Window cleaner Nick said: As soon as England won I was straight onto the wedding planner. But it is not as easy as you think. The photographer is into football too so was happy to accommodate us. “They were all very thoughtful and moved the wedding at The Courtyard forward and the reception at Greens of Gretna to 5.30pm. “We are massive England fans.”

title: mutant pig deformed human like
story: NewsMutant pig with deformed 'human-like' face caught on camera in ChinaA villager is seen holding the animal towards the camera in the unsettling minute-long video&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNeil Murphy05:42, 7 JUL 2018Updated06:08, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBizarre new footage from China shows a newborn baby pig with a disturbingly HUMAN-like face.
